title: Maruti wants a sleepy market to smell the S-Presso, but can this mini SUV replace the trusty Alto?
text:
It’s kitted with in-vehicle infotainment and the same engine that powers the Alto K10. Maruti Suzuki is betting on the S-Presso to create a new segment and ease the pressure on the Alto. Though the carmaker has a proven track record with multiple models in the same category, this one may be a tough one to crack.

Maruti Suzuki’s managing director and CEO Kenichi Ayukawa

of the new launches in the last six months have been SUVs or SUVs lookalikes, while hatchbacks have been on the decline, says automotive columnist Murad Ali Baig. “Buyers want SUVish looks, so Maruti has also glammed up. S-Presso will keep internal competition going, clipping demand of the Datsun and Renault vehicles,” he adds.
